items.title: Failed to install pydash on Windows due to non-ascii char
items.body:
pydash fails to install on Windows with the following error:

```
Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\basecommand.py", line 215, in main
    status = self.run(options, args)
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\commands\install.py", line 312, in run
    wheel_cache
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\basecommand.py", line 295, in populate_requirement_set
    wheel_cache=wheel_cache):
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\req\req_file.py", line 84, in parse_requirements
    filename, comes_from=comes_from, session=session
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\download.py", line 422, in get_file_content
    content = auto_decode(f.read())
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\utils\encoding.py", line 31, in auto_decode
    return data.decode(locale.getpreferredencoding(False))
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\encodings\cp1252.py", line 15, in decode
    return codecs.charmap_decode(input,errors,decoding_table)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x9d in position 798: character maps to <undefined>
```

This happens due to non-ascii characters in file `strings.py`:
- https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/4bbadc967b51518e300a1368357bbe71959313ec/src/pydash/strings.py#L368
- https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/4bbadc967b51518e300a1368357bbe71959313ec/src/pydash/strings.py#L1385

After fixing them, the installation fails with another error:
```
Collecting pydash>=4.7.6 (from -r D:\Cloudinator\Worker\test-migration-dcsplus\requirements.txt (line 28))
Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\basecommand.py", line 215, in main
    status = self.run(options, args)
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\commands\install.py", line 324, in run
    requirement_set.prepare_files(finder)
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\req\req_set.py", line 380, in prepare_files
    ignore_dependencies=self.ignore_dependencies))
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\req\req_set.py", line 664, in _prepare_file
    dist = abstract_dist.dist(finder)
  File "c:\program files\python36\lib\site-packages\pip\req\req_set.py", line 110, in dist
    self.req_to_install.source_dir))[0]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

Does the library even support installation on Windows?

items.title: Have collections.includes search for dicts
items.body:
Currently, [collections.includes](https://pydash.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#pydash.collections.at) only allows searching for values:
```sh
>>> includes({'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3, 'd': 4}, 2)
True
```
It should also allow for keys and dicts:
```sh
>>> includes({'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3, 'd': 4}, 'a')
True
>>> includes({'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3, 'd': 4}, {'a': 1})
True
```

items.title: pick_by has different behaviour with lodash.pickBy
items.body:
```
In [1]: import pydash

In [2]: pydash.pick_by({'a': 1, 'b': 0})
Out[2]: {}

In [3]: pydash.pick_by({'a': 1, 'b': 0}, lambda i: i)
Out[3]: {'a': 1}

```
Expected behaviour: `pydash.pick_by({'a': 1, 'b': 0})` will return `{'a': 1}`

Actual behaviour: return `{}`

Following is the behaviour in Lodash
```
> _.pickBy({a: 1, b: 0})
< {a: 1}
```

items.title: crash in `collections.order_by()` if ordering key is named 'value'
items.body:
Example:
```
$ python3
Python 3.7.7
[GCC 7.5.0] on linux
>>> py_.order_by([{'value': 1}], 'value')
[{'value': 1}]

>>> py_.order_by([{'value': 1}, {'value': 2}], 'value')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 675, in order_by
    return sorted(collection, key=cmp_to_key(comparison), reverse=reverse)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 669, in comparison
    result = _cmp(func(left), func(right))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/pydash/_compat.py", line 86, in _cmp
    def _cmp(a, b): return (a > b) - (a < b)
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'NoneType'

>>> py_.order_by([{'v': 1}, {'v': 2}], 'v')
[{'v': 1}, {'v': 2}]
```

items.title: An error is raised if using partial function with for_each operator
items.body:
Hi there,

My python version is 3.6.9, and pydash version is 4.7.6. I can repro this issue by a simple code like below:

```python
from pydash import py_
from pydash.functions import partial


def foo(a, b):
    print(f"{a},{b}")


foo_a = partial(foo, b=3)
py_([1, 2, 3]).for_each(foo_a).value()
```

If I run it, an error is raised:

```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "pydash_bug1.py", line 10, in <module>
    py_([1, 2, 3]).for_each(foo_a).value()
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/chaining.py", line 35, in value
    return self(self._value)
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/chaining.py", line 140, in __call__
    value = self._value.unwrap(value)
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/chaining.py", line 182, in unwrap
    return wrapper.method(value, *wrapper.args, **wrapper.kargs)
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 340, in for_each
    None)
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 338, in <genexpr>
    next((None for ret, _, _, _ in iteriteratee(collection, iteratee)
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/helpers.py", line 97, in iteriteratee
    yield (callit(cbk, item, key, obj, argcount=argcount),
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/helpers.py", line 38, in callit
    return iteratee(*args[:argstop])
  File "/home/tester/Codes/github/venvs/Linux.4.15.0-91-generic.cpython3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/functions.py", line 313, in __call__
    return self.func(*args, **kargs)
TypeError: foo() got multiple values for argument 'b'
```

I guess [_getfullargspec](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/develop/src/pydash/helpers.py#L70) try to get argument spec of `__call__` function of a `pydash.functions.Partial` instance. `__call__` always has 3 arguments `self`, `*args`, `**kwargs`. However our intent is the argument spec of the function wrapped by `pydash.functions.Partial`  (in my example, it should be `foo`, which has 2 arguments `a` and `b`) . Finally an incorrect [`argcount`](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/develop/src/pydash/helpers.py#L38) causes this issue.

Is it a known issue, or do I misuse `for_each` or `partial`? Definitely there is a workaround for this issue:

```python
from pydash import py_
from pydash.functions import partial


def foo(a, b):
    print(f"{a},{b}")


foo_a = partial(foo, b=3)
py_([1, 2, 3]).for_each(lambda x: foo_a(x)).value()
```

Just in case, the author wants to fix this issue.

items.title: crash in `collections.order_by()` if None in one of ordering keys
items.body:
Hello.

Found very unpleasant bug when worked with sorting.
Hope, this can be fixed soon =)

(attached code which should fix it below)

1. if None in one of ordering keys

```python
import pydash
collections_0_4 = [{'a': 1, 'b': 3}, {'a': 1, 'b': None}]
result_0_4 = pydash.collections.order_by(collections_0_4, ['a', 'b'])
```

error: 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/vlad/Temp/issue_pydash/issue_reproduce.py", line 13, in <module>
    result_0_3 = pydash.collections.order_by(collections_0_3, ['a', 'b'])    # reproduced
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 675, in order_by
    return sorted(collection, key=cmp_to_key(comparison), reverse=reverse)
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 669, in comparison
    result = _cmp(func(left), func(right))
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/_compat.py", line 86, in _cmp
    def _cmp(a, b): return (a > b) - (a < b)
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'NoneType'
```

2. if one of ordering keys missing

```python
import pydash
collections_6 = [{'a': 0, 'b': 1}, {'a': 0, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}, {'a': 0, 'b': 3, 'c': 4}]
result_6 = pydash.collections.order_by(collections_6, ['a', 'c'])
```

error: 
```
$ pipenv run python '/home/vlad/Temp/issue_pydash/issue_reproduce.py' 
another issue not reproduced if this message is visible
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/vlad/Temp/issue_pydash/issue_reproduce.py", line 35, in <module>
    result_6 = pydash.collections.order_by(collections_6, ['a', 'c'])    # reproduced
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 675, in order_by
    return sorted(collection, key=cmp_to_key(comparison), reverse=reverse)
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py", line 669, in comparison
    result = _cmp(func(left), func(right))
  File "/home/vlad/.local/share/virtualenvs/issue_pydash-TqXHV2Jm/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/_compat.py", line 86, in _cmp
    def _cmp(a, b): return (a > b) - (a < b)
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'int' and 'NoneType'
```

my fixed version of `order_by()` function:

```python
def sort_elements(array: 'list of dict', sort_by_keys: list):
    sort_by_keys.reverse()
    array_sorted = array

    for key in sort_by_keys:
        reverse = False

        if key.startswith('-'):
            reverse = True
            key     = key[1:]

        def get_absolute_value_for_comparing_element(element: dict):
            nonlocal key
            nonlocal reverse
            abs_value_if_key_missing = - math.inf if reverse else math.inf
            is_key_missing           = not key in element
            is_key_none              = not is_key_missing and (element.get(key) is None)

            if is_key_missing or is_key_none:
                abs_value = abs_value_if_key_missing
            else:
                abs_value = element.get(key)
            return abs_value

        array_sorted = sorted(array_sorted, key=get_absolute_value_for_comparing_element, reverse=reverse)

    return array_sorted
```

Think, it's more explicit than current implementation - _cmp function implicitly transformed to new format, than used.

File with details how to reproduce error, just run it,
everything marked with "reproduced" will throw error:
[issue_reproduce.txt](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/files/4200959/issue_reproduce.txt)

My fixed version of `order_by()` with tests:
[try_to_fix.txt](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/files/4200974/try_to_fix.txt)

Best regards,
Vladislav

items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences in Python 3.8
items.body:
Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences in Python 3.8 . Below is a log of the warnings raised during compiling all the python files. Using raw strings or escaping them will fix this issue.

```
find . -iname '*.py'  | xargs -P 4 -I{} python -Wall -m py_compile {}

./tests/test_strings.py:201: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \[
  '\[pydash\]\(http\:\/\/pydash\.readthedocs\.org\/\)'),
./tests/test_strings.py:343: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \s
  ('F\n\soO Bar', 'f so o bar'),
./tests/test_strings.py:927: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \s
  ('F\n\soO Bar', 'F SO O BAR'),
./tests/test_strings.py:982: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \;
  ('hello!@#$%^&*()_+{}|:"<>?-=[]\;\,.\'/world', ['hello', 'world']),
```

items.title: Use with Namespaces (or other plain python objects
items.body: Hi, I was using argparse Namespaces as dict-like objects with a shorter, more JS-like syntax (at least when you don't dynamical values and have to use `getattr` and `setattr`).  It seems that with these values, I can use paths with pydash `get` but not with pydash `set`.  And `set_with` doesn't seem to help because it still wants to subscript the object (afaiu).  I was just wondering if there is a recommended solution to this issue.  Are there versions of the functions that work more like JS and don't work with dicts instead of POPOs?

items.title: Setting an element in array by it's index will create a dict instead of an array
items.body:
```
from pydash import py_ as _
company = {}
_.set(company, 'contacts.0.name', 'Joe')
```
will return
```
{'contacts': {'0': {'name': 'Joe'}}}
```
instead of
```
{'contacts': [{'name': 'Joe'}]}
```
as the original lodash would return.

items.title: collections.count_by unhashable type dict
items.body:
If I have an array of dictionaries, and want to count the number of instances that match each other can that be done using count_by?

e.g. [ {'a':1,'b':2},{'a':1,'b':1'},{'a':1,'b':2'}]
 
The result would be: [ {'a':1,'b':2}:2,{'a':1,'b':1'}:1]

If not what's the best approach (I have used a tuple but am looking for a cleaner way of doing this)

items.title: pick_by has different behavior with iteratee=None compared to lodash
items.body: In Lodash the default iteratee is `_.identity` (for all fooBy functions) so `_.pickBy(x)` returns a dictionary with only those keys that have truthy values. I can't figure out what `pydash.pick_by(x)` does. It seems to always return an empty dictionary.

items.title: Comparators should handle None
items.body:
Found on pydash 4.7.4

One of the things that made lodash great is its flexibility around null-handling... lodash seems to be opiniated that a null reference should just do something reasonable instead of throwing an exception.

In pydash, I noticed comparators are not null-safe. Consider:

```python
some_list = [{'a': 4}, {'a': 1}, {'b': 'Bb'}]
pydash.order_by(some_list, ['a'])
```

In lodash, this does something reasonable -- the 'b' item is put at the end.

In pydash, accessing `some_list[2]['a']` seems to internally resolve to None (great!), but then the comparator breaks trying to compare None to the other values:

```
.../python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py in order_by(collection, keys, orders, reverse)
    673             return 0
    674
--> 675     return sorted(collection, key=cmp_to_key(comparison), reverse=reverse)
    676
    677

.../python3.6/site-packages/pydash/collections.py in comparison(left, right)
    667         # pylint: disable=useless-else-on-loop,missing-docstring
    668         for func, mult in comparers:
--> 669             result = _cmp(func(left), func(right))
    670             if result:
    671                 return mult * result

.../python3.6/site-packages/pydash/_compat.py in _cmp(a, b)
     84     izip = zip
     85
---> 86     def _cmp(a, b): return (a > b) - (a < b)
     87
     88

TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'int'
```

Expected Results: comparator-handling of None is handled in a reasonable way instead of crashing

items.title: [BUG] deep_clone_with failed due to iterable string
items.body:
```python
import pydash
pydash.clone_deep_with('a', lambda a:None)
```

This would fail. The string 'a' is iterable, and the children is `['a']`.

items.title: pydash.find fails with dict.values() on Python 3
items.body: When running `pydash.find` over `somedict.values()`, it fails with: `'dict_values' object does not support indexing` in Python 3. It is not a simple list but a [dictionary view object](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dictionary-view-objects). I would expect that pydash shall be able to browse through it anyway.

items.title: Problem with objects.set_()
items.body:
Hi,
I'm using pydash 4.7.3 on python 3.6.3 on macOS Mojave 10.14.
I have a problem with the method objects.set_().
If I execute `objects.set_({}, 'a.b', {'n':3})` everything work fine and `{'a': {'b': {'c': {'n': 3}}}}` is returned.
Instead if I execute `objects.set_({'a': None}, 'a.b.c', {'n':3})` an exception is thrown:
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/abc/.pyenv/versions/def/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/objects.py", line 1668, in update_with
    target = target[key]
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable
During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/abc/.pyenv/versions/def/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/objects.py", line 1201, in set_
    return set_with(obj, path, value)
  File "/Users/abc/.pyenv/versions/def/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/objects.py", line 1233, in set_with
    return update_with(obj, path, pyd.constant(value), customizer=customizer)
  File "/Users/abc/.pyenv/versions/def/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pydash/objects.py", line 1670, in update_with
    target = target[int(key)]
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'b'
```

Is it a bug or am I wrong?

items.title: to_path treats lists and tuples differently
items.body:
It's surprising that [to_path treats lists and tuples differently](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/12571340029f75e03ad0c2d62fd8494423e59724/src/pydash/utilities.py#L1147)

Example:

    >>> import pydash
    >>> d = {'a': {'b': {'c': 42}}}
    >>> pydash.objects.get(d, ('a', 'b', 'c'))
    >>> pydash.objects.get(d, ['a', 'b', 'c'])
    42

It looks very un-pythonic to me.

If there is a reason behind this, it should be documented.

If it's a bug, I can make a pull request. It will require a new major release as it breaks backward compatibility. I think that using a single tuple as single key is a relatively rare use case: why would a person use pydash for that?

Also, as a more general duck-typing approach, I propose converting *anything* iterable, except strings, into a list. It can be done [here](https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/12571340029f75e03ad0c2d62fd8494423e59724/src/pydash/utilities.py#L1230).

items.title: uniq functions time complexity
items.body:
This implementation of uniq with the usage of arrays as the collection of seen items has clearly a (worst case) time complexity of O(n^2). However in case of input items are hashable, a linear implementation can be achieved by using a hashset here instead. Please make the method more efficient or at least add some warnings about this in the docstrings.

https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/cb103ca6363cc5d497c116b11534aa18bf177a2f/pydash/arrays.py#L2291

```
import time
from datetime import datetime
import pydash as py_
s = datetime.now()
py_.uniq(range(10000))
t = datetime.now()
print(t-s)
```
`0:00:42.274382`

items.title: List inside object breaks objects.defaults_deep
items.body:
```pydash.objects.defaults_deep({}, {'elasticsearch': {'hosts': ['es-0.0.0.0:9200']}}, {'elasticsearch': {'hosts': ['1.0.0.0:9200']}})```

Throws an error. `AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'setdefault'`
Expected result is the object contains - that it should treat the list as a 'whole' 

` {'elasticsearch': {'hosts': ['es-0.0.0.0:9200']}}`

python 3.6.3
pydash 4.3.1

items.title: Curried Functions Being Reduced Will throw positional argument error
items.body:
```python
import pydash as _
@_.curry
def curried_function(data, accum, id):
    accum[id] = _.reduce_(data, sum)
    return accum

ids = [1]
data = [1,2]
curried_function_with_data = curried_function(data)
_.reduce_(ids, curried_function_with_data, {}) #throws Error since it tries to callit with index since argscount = 3.
```

Can the function getargcount subtract from the amount of args the function already has?

Also im very interested in getting started in open source, so wouldn't mind contributing if you think this might be useful.

items.title: In pick(), if dict value is a callable, it will be called and the return value will be used instead of being returned as-is.
items.body:
Offending example:

```python
>>> import pydash
>>> pydash.pick({'a': lambda: 1}, 'a')
{'a': 1}
```

This should return something like `{'a': <function <lambda> at 0x7fa5572b0e18>}` instead.

items.title: Better API documentation search
items.body:
Hello Pydash,

love the project, great fan of lodash and see even more need for a library like this in Python-land.

My big issue right now is that the documentation is very hard to search / read in general, this is mostly due to the readthedocs UI. I'm sure you're aware of the excellent way of searching the lodash documentation, this feature alone makes me come back to this library every time. I'd appreciate it if lodash had a similarly easy-to-search API documentation. To outline what I mean, here is me searching for "get" in both search boxes.

![lodash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10496846/33117243-fd2851b8-cf67-11e7-945c-db7e92f03597.png)
![pydash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10496846/33117244-fd4417a4-cf67-11e7-8076-463b435545a3.png)

items.title: _.cond doesn't work as expected
pydash.objects.omit doesn't support nested paths
Generators
items.body:
I feel pydash is the library to do functional programming in python with more functions, and it is so sweet if you work with lodash too :-).

As a matter of efficiency when dealing with bigger data, I started to make heavy use of generators, avoiding storing intermediate big pieces of data. Unfortunately, pydash returns lists/dicts instead of generators.

By doing otherwise, we could pass that generator to another function that would query the values as needed, avoiding the cost in memory of using intermediate values –and we can always do list(my_generator).

Pydash already accept iterators as input values and you already perform lazy evaluation when chaining (although I don't know if you use internally generators for that), so some steps are already there.

A practical example would be getting data from a database and process it. In python many db libraries return a generator. This generator is passed-in in some chained methods in pydash, returning a second generator, and the second generator is passed-in to other functions that, in last instance, require the value. Computation of the value is only done in the end.

Toolz explains this [here](https://toolz.readthedocs.io/en/latest/laziness.html).

items.title: FP Implementation
items.body:
Hi Folks,

Great library, been using it over the last month or two and enjoying it.  I was just wondering if anyone has ever looked into porting over FP?  I quite like using `flow` which really necessitates 'auto-curried iteratee-first data-last' functions to quote the FP blurb.  I've taken a look at how FP is written and would be up for implementing something similar in pydash if you think it's a sensible idea!  If so I'll get something together and make a PR.

Cheers,

Patrick

items.title: object:get, documentation describes the other behavior from lodash
items.body:
Hello!

Documentation for `get` method differs from the docs for an appropriate method of **lodash**.

[Lodash get](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#get):

```js
var object = { 'a': [{ 'b': { 'c': 3 } }] };
_.get(object, 'a[0].b.c');
// => 3
```

[Pydash get](http://pydash.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#pydash.objects.get):

```python
get({'a': {'b': {'c': [1, 2, 3, 4]}}}, 'a.b.c.1')
# => 2
```

As you could see, list/array access differs (`a[0].b.c` vs `a.b.c.1`). But original lodash syntax works as expected:

```python
get({'a': {'b': {'c': [1, 2, 3, 4]}}}, 'a.b.c[1]')
# => 2
```

The point is to update docs (because it is a little bit confusing now)

Thank you!

items.title: Add replace_start() and replace_end()
items.body: These replace methods should have a similar function signature to `pydash.replace` but only replace text at the beginning or end of a string.

items.title: Concatenating None
items.body:
Concatenating when source is `None` produces the following:
```python
pydash.concat(None, [1]) == [None,1]
```
The expected output is:
```python
pydash.concat(None, [1]) == [1]
```

Happens in Pydash 3.4.8 and 4.0.3 under macOS 10.12.4, Python 3.4.

PS: magnificent library!

items.title: py_.intersection returns an empty set if no *others are given
items.body:
This is a difference between 4.0.1 and 3.4.8 that i cannot really resolve.

    $ pip install pydash==3.4.8
    >>> py_.intersection([1, 2, 3], [1, 2])
    [1, 2]
    >>> py_.intersection([1, 2, 3])
    [1, 2, 3]

And now:

    $ pip install pydash==4.0.1
    >>> py_.intersection([1, 2, 3], [1, 2])
    [1, 2]
    >>> py_.intersection([1, 2, 3])
    []

I call `py_.intersection` with a set of arrays like `common_values = py_.intersection(*list_of_lists)`, so i run into this problem if my list_of_lists contains only a single list.

items.title: no replacement for deep_pluck with list argument
items.body:
With the upgrade to version 4, there seems to be no equal replacement for `deep_pluck` with a list as argument.The recommended `.map` call has a different behavior.

Version 3.4.8:

    >>> py_.deep_pluck([{1: {2: {3: 4}}}], [1, 2])
    [{3: 4}]

Version 4.0.0:

    >>> py_.map([{1: {2: {3: 4}}}], [1, 2])
    [False]

The only workaround i found was:

    >>> py_.map([{1: {2: {3: 4}}}], py_.property_deep([1, 2]))
    [{3: 4}]

items.title: Remove all alias functions
items.body:
Time to get rid of aliases to cut down on the multitude of different ways to invoke the same function. This is primarily to help enforce the "there should be one way to do it" mantra of Python within other libraries/applications that use pydash. Having the potential for different function names that call the same function can make debugging more difficult and grepping harder since you have to take into account all the aliases of a function to find where it is being used.

Can use Lodash's own [deprecations page](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Deprecations) as a guide but I'd like to eliminate *all* aliases.

items.title: get goes b00m
items.body:
This is fine:

```python
from pydash import (
    get
)
cow = {'Body': {'result': True}}
print("cow: " + str(cow))
grab = get(cow, 'Body.result', False)
print("grab: " + str(grab))
```

However, change 'Body' to lowercase in the `get`:

```python
grab = get(cow, 'body.result', False)
```

... and she ain't so safe anymore, doesn't return false and instead raises this:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "testing.py", line 6, in <module>
    grab = get(cow, 'body.result', False)
  File "/Users/lpq389/myenv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pydash/objects.py", line 511, in get
    obj = get_item(obj, key, default=default)
  File "/Users/lpq389/myenv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pydash/helpers.py", line 128, in get_item
    ret = obj[int(key)]
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'result'
```

I'm looking at the code now to see if I can fix (I suck at Python, hence my life depending on Pydash). Workaround is to just wrap her in a try/except.

items.title: When get_item returns the default value, pydash.objects.get continues evaluating the key path
items.body:
If the remaining keys are in the default value, you'll get the value inside the default value supplied to get instead of the default value itself.

Operating System: Mac OS X 10.11.5 (El Capitan)
Steps to reproduce:

1. In a python REPL with pydash installed, type:
```
import pydash

obj = {'one': {'two': {'three': 4}}}
default_value = [{'a': 1}]
value = pydash.get(obj, 'one.four.0.a', default=default_value)
value
```

2. `value` will be 1 instead of `[{'a': 1}]` because while processing the 'four' key, get_item returns the default value and get continues with '0.a'

items.title: ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10 in get
items.body:
Operating System: MacOS X 10.11.5 (El Capitan)
Python versions: 2.7, 3.4, 3.5
Pydash version: 3.4.5
Reproduction steps:

1. In a Python virtualenv with pydash as a pip dependency, open a Python REPL and enter:
```
import pydash
a = { 'a': { 'b': { 'c': { 'd': [] } } } }
pydash.get(a, 'a.b.e.d', [])
``` 
2. You will get a TypeError stating that list indices must be integers, not str, followed by:
```
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'd'
```

It should have returned the default value `[]`

items.title: bug: is_match() fails when comparing empty iterables
items.body: The `is_match()` function should return `True` if two iterables are the same type and are empty.

items.title: default value for max_, min_
items.body:
It'll be very useful to be able to pass in default value for empty collections  (like Python3)
coll = []
max_(coll, callback=lambda x: x*x, default=0)

currently, it'll error with max() arg

items.title: Why does pydash have map_?
items.body:
Hi there,

Great work on this library, super useful as someone who comes from the JS lodash world.

I was wondering why pydash duplicates in-built functions such as map, given that pydash equivalents are significantly slower when benchmarked with `%timeit` in ipynb.

items.title: objects.merge docs don't match implementation
items.body:
In particular, docs for merge say:

```
If the callback returns undefined merging will be handled by the method instead.
```

`undefined` in this context appears to be an artifact of a port from lodash... and looking at the implementation, the result of the callback is not considered.

The easy fix is to delete that sentence. Perhaps better would be to implement support for that functionality, perhaps by testing for `is NoValue`, and update the documentation to match that.

items.title: deep_get cannot index nested arrays
items.body:
Is this supposed to work in pydash?

```
In [4]: o=[{"hits":{"hits":[{"_source":5}]}}]

In [5]: pydash.deep_get(o, '[0].hits.hits[0]._source') # this is supposed to return 5

In [6]: pydash.deep_get(o, '[0].hits.hits')
Out[6]: [{'_source': 5}]

In [7]: pydash.deep_get(o, '[0].hits.hits[0]')

```

It works fine in lodash:

```
> o=[{"hits":{"hits":[{"_source":5}]}}]
[ { hits: { hits: [Object] } } ]
> l.get(o, '[0].hits.hits[0]._source')
5
```

items.title: startCase
items.body:
I'm looking for an python implementation of [startCase.](https://lodash.com/docs#startCase)

Thoughts on how this might be done and should it end up in here?

PS: it was [added to lodash Feb 1, 2015](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/908/files)

items.title: This library is amazing
items.body:
I do a lot of development using lodash and lodash-fp. I got to say, this library is a godsend for similar functionality in Python. It makes porting existing lodash-centric logic a lot easier as well. I hope this project doesn't die. Is there some sort of established relationship with lodash itself? We should promote the use of this more.
Thanks for your efforts :+1:

items.title: Just Curious: Why so slow?
items.body:
As a precursor to my question: I'm not here to cast doubt upon the usefulness of this project or the adequacy of those who have worked on it. In truth I am very impressed by this project and when I first discovered it I began using it in most of my projects! (I do lots of data mining, so a library such as this is priceless.)

But I noticed recently that some of the functions in Pydash are very slow compared to their Python counterparts. For instance consider the following code: 

```
from pydash import filter_

In [.]: x = [{'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}, {'a': 2, 'b': 3, 'c': 4}]
In [.]: %timeit filter_(x, {'a': 1})
10000 loops, best of 3: 62.1 µs per loop

In [.]: %timeit filter(lambda y: y['a'] is 1, x)
1000000 loops, best of 3: 417 ns per loop
```

Now in truth I would never expect the Pydash equivalent functions to be _faster_ than the Python counterpart, but _~150x slower_?

Any idea how the speed of these functions could be improved? Since I made this performance discovery I've stopped using the pydash library so much and went back to filter + lambda...but goodness that can get ugly! I love the idea of this library, I just wished performance was better.

items.title: Allow late passing of value to pydash.chain
items.body:
Implement the following use case:

``` python
square_sum = pydash.chain().power(2).sum()

# possibly use a method called "execute"
assert square_sum.execute([1, 2, 3, 4]) == 30

# or maybe even allow __call__ to work
assert square_sum([1, 2, 3, 4]) == 30
```

items.title: Review function signatures for compatibility with chaining.
items.body: Mainly looking for any functions that could be made compatible with chaining (i.e. first argument would be the chained value). If functions aren't compatible, consider modifying them to be.

items.title: Shouldn't string functions be None-safe?
items.body:
I found that string functions aren't consistently `None`-safe, i.e. `trunc`, `camel_case`, ... are `None`-safe but `explode` and others aren't.

I propose string functions to be `None`-safe as is in [Apache Commons Lang](http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/index.html) and in [underscore.string](https://github.com/epeli/underscore.string).

I also propose: `_.to_string(None)` returns `''` instead of `'None'` actually.

items.title: Ensure string ends with a given suffix
items.body:
I suggest adding a function which appends a given suffix to a string, but only if the source string does not end with that suffix.

```
def ensure_ends_with(text, suffix):
    """Append a given suffix to a string, but only if the source string does not end with that suffix.
        Args:
            text (str): Source string to append `suffix` to
            suffix (str): String to append to the source string if the source string does not end with `suffix`
        Returns:
            str: source string possibly extended by `suffix`
        .. versionadded:: 2.0.0
    """
    return text if text.endsWith(suffix) else text + suffix
```

As I'm not a native speaker, for me it's not clear how to name that function. My suggestion is `ensure_ends_with`or is `make_ending_with` better?

items.title: merge() results in linked dicts
items.body:
Failing test case:

``` python
some_dict = {'foo': {'bar': None}}
new_dict = merge({}, some_dict)
new_dict['foo']['bar'] = 'baz'
assert some_dict['foo']['bar'] == new_dict['foo']['bar']
```

Expected:

``` python
assert some_dict['foo']['bar'] is None
```

items.title: Add missing array methods for feature parity with Lodash chaining
items.body:
Pydash is currently missing the following chain methods that Lodash supports:
- [x] concat
- [x] join
- [x] pop
- [x] push
- [x] reverse
- [x] shift
- [x] slice (exists as `slice_`)
- [x] sort
- [x] splice
- [x] unshift

These need to be add as pydash functions in order to be made available for chaining.

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.body:
In Lo-Dash:

``` javascript
.omit([1,2,3]) == {'0': 1, '1': 2, '2': 3}
```

In pydash

``` python
pydash.omit([1, 2, 3], lambda x, *args: x)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "pydash/objects.py", line 300, in omit
    return dict((key, value) for key, value in iteritems(obj)
  File "pydash/_compat.py", line 38, in <lambda>
    iteritems = lambda d: d.iteritems()
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'iteritems'
```

**NOTE:** Even though Lo-Dash returns string keys, pydash should use integers.

items.title: values() should work with lists

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

In Lo-Dash:

``` javascript
_.values([1, 2, 3]) == [1, 2, 3]
```

In pydash:

``` python
pydash.values([1, 2, 3])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "pydash/objects.py", line 350, in values
    return list(itervalues(obj))
  File "pydash/_compat.py", line 37, in <lambda>
    itervalues = lambda d: d.itervalues()
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'itervalues'
```

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.body:
In Lo-Dash:

``` javascript
_.pairs([1, 2, 3]) == [['0', 1], ['1', 1], ['2', 2]]
```

In pydash:

``` python
pydash.pairs([1, 2, 3])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "pydash/objects.py", line 308, in pairs
    return [[key, value] for key, value in iteritems(obj)]
  File "pydash/_compat.py", line 38, in <lambda>
    iteritems = lambda d: d.iteritems()
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'iteritems'
```

**NOTE:** Even though Lo-Dash returns string keys, pydash should use integers.

items.title: pick() should work with lists

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.body:
In Lo-Dash:

``` javascript
_.pick([1, 2, 3], 0) == {'0': 1}
```

In pydash:

``` python
pydash.pick([1,2,3], 0)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "pydash/objects.py", line 322, in pick
    return dict((key, value) for key, value in iteritems(obj)
  File "pydash/_compat.py", line 38, in <lambda>
    iteritems = lambda d: d.iteritems()
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'iteritems'
```

**NOTE:** Even though Lo-Dash returns string keys, pydash should use integers.

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.title: Resolve circular import issues

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.body:
Relevant warts:
- https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/dcda594046c51da6ab3dfc4697de4532990472bb/pydash/arrays.py#L340
- https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/dcda594046c51da6ab3dfc4697de4532990472bb/pydash/collections.py#L20
- https://github.com/dgilland/pydash/blob/dcda594046c51da6ab3dfc4697de4532990472bb/pydash/utils.py#L11

Refs #9 

Possible solutions:
1. Keep circular imports in place.
2. Move common functions to `utils.py` and alias into corresponding file (e.g. move `collections.where` to utils.where`and then create an alias to`where`in`collections`).
3. Use an absolute import of `pydash` in target files and then reference circular dependencies through that.

milestone.title: v1.0.0
milestone.description: Version 1 release should be feature complete with Lodash with the exception of any Lodash feature that may not fit well with Python (e.g. `isRegExp`, `isArray`, etc.).

items.title: Current status of this project?
items.body:
Hey, I'm a great admirer of lodash and searching for a python replacement for it.
Isn't on pypi, not manifest file or setup.py. so no way to install now. Is this in active development?
